bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 7, 1928

div1.p: Carter and Brown continue to work on the bibliography for the History of Yellow Fever despite the brutal Washington, D.C. heat.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 7, 1928
div1.opener:
Books
Misel. (Report
weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
August 7, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have gotten in another good week's work on
the bibliography, despite the heat, which has been a horror. In this
connection, the passes, so thoughtfully given us by Colonel Ashburn, have
been a great help, enabling us to start work before official opening time
(in the--comparatively!--cool part of the day) etc. Also, thanks to her
pass, and her own interest in the work, Miss Brown spent all Saturday and
afternoon and evening and all day Sunday working at the S. G's Library with
most satisfactory results. I also got in a good deal of work in this
“off time,” but had to do it at home on account of the palliative treatment
still needed after the extraction of my teeth. Yesterday, however, the
packing was taken out, laalso a loose piece of bone, so I hope that the
worst is over. It has been bad though. Practically no time lost, however,
for Aas I said, in my last letter, thanks to Colonel Ashburn, I can work
at home with books from the Library of the Surgeon General. Inedeed I'm
doing so to-day, thus saving the time spent in coming and going, quite an
item in my case. If I can get all my pagination [unclear] to-day on the books I've taken out, Miss Brown is
coming up to my apartment this afternnoon and we'll check references both
before and after dinner.

I'm so glad to see that the heat wave has broken in New York, for you
must have all been having a hard time of it. The “weather man” doesn't
hold out any hopes to us yet, although it is cloud.ly to-day, hence not so
bad as yesterday.
With very best wishes, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
